headline: Opinion | JD Vance, Melania Trump and Pope Francis walk into a (Midwestern) joke - The Washington Post
context: Every week, The Post runs a collection of letters of readers’ grievances — pointing out grammatical mistakes, missing coverage and inconsistencies. These letters tell us what we did wrong and, occasionally, offer praise. Here, we present this week’s Free for All letters.

Pope Francis called us to act on one simple truth: our shared humanity. He called us to God’s expectation that we recognize the humble divinity within each of us and treat one another with respect. Have feeding and caring for the poor become unworthy goals? Are those now solely “liberal” endeavors?

annotations.paragraph: I respectfully ask Michael Ramirez, author of the April 22 editorial cartoon, “Pope Francis at peace,” to reread and reconsider some of the pope’s writings and addresses. Francis spoke of the globalization of indifference toward one another. He urged us to greater kindness, to greater mindfulness of the well-being of humanity as a whole. He spoke of our obligation to God to do this.

annotations.paragraph: As a resident of the “Upper Midwest,” I always found it difficult to view Ohio as Midwestern. But Easterners seem to feel that Ohio is the beginning of the Midwest, apparently as a carryover from the time of the Louisiana Purchase, when the land now known as Ohio was part of the the “Northwest Territory.” As such, Minnesota is often referenced as part of the “Northwest,” as opposed to Washington state, which is referred to as part of the “Pacific Northwest.” Let’s face it, geography and regional names often do not correlate to logical locations.

annotations.paragraph: As a frequent traveler all over the country, I have to say that many of the cities I visited in the Midwest, albeit briefly, were dull and boring. I used to muse on those cities where I would not live. Chicago is great, but Des Moines is a yawn. Ames, Iowa, and Ann Arbor, Michigan, are fabulous. But no to Detroit and Kansas City. I loved Cleveland and even Cincinnati, but Akron is nothing to write home about. Omaha was acceptable; Wichita, not so much. Moving south, forget both Tulsa and Oklahoma City. (I could never get the dust off of my shoes.) Houston and San Antonio were good, but I couldn’t stand Dallas. Little Rock was surprisingly pleasant, but Jackson, Mississippi, a few hours southeast, was just plain poor. “Rust Belt” might be a misnomer, but the idea is real. That’s why most of us live on the coasts.

annotations.paragraph: Though plagiarism and other intellectual theft have long been problems in schools, the number of such cases I see as a faculty adviser to a high school honor council has grown exponentially with the rise of artificial intelligence. Schools endeavor to teach students proper ways to use both print and electronic resources such as ChatGPT in their writing and how to cite those resources when they do. One facet of that process that most students do not appear to struggle with is knowing that they must credit the poet when copying an entire poem word for word. The editor of the Free for All page seems to have missed that lesson in school. On April 19, the caption for the beautiful picture of the Chicago skyline was one of my favorite short poems, “Fog” by Carl Sandburg, included in its 21-word entirety with no credit given to Sandburg. Please give artists credit for their work and refrain from leading students to believe it is permissible to steal another’s work and present it as one’s own.
